title: How to Get a Real Estate License in Florida: 2025 Guide
excerpt: Getting your Florida real estate license might seem daunting, but with the right guidance, it’s a straightforward process. This comprehensive guide will walk you through…
content:
Getting your Florida real estate license might seem daunting, but with the right guidance, it’s a straightforward process. This comprehensive guide will walk you through each step, ensuring you’re well-prepared to start your real estate career in Florida. Let’s get started on your journey to becoming a licensed real estate agent.

  1. Basic Requirements
  2. Choosing a Real Estate School
  3. Find a Sponsoring Broker
  4. Why Join Smart Agent Alliance?

Basic Requirements

Before diving into the specifics, it’s essential to understand the basic requirements for obtaining a Florida real estate license. These are the fundamental criteria you must meet:

Applicants must be at least 18 years old to apply for a real estate license in Florida. This age requirement ensures that individuals have reached a necessary level of maturity and legal responsibility for the profession.

You don’t need to be a Florida resident to obtain a license, but you must have a Social Security number. This identification is crucial for background checks and ensures compliance with state regulations. Out-of-state applicants must meet the same criteria as Florida residents.

Honesty and integrity are paramount. The Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) will conduct a thorough background check, and any conviction of a crime may result in the denial of your license. Being upfront about any past legal issues and demonstrating rehabilitation can positively impact your application.

In Florida, you need to complete 63 hours of pre-licensing education. This course covers essential topics like real estate principles, practices, and Florida-specific laws.

This comprehensive course covers the fundamentals of real estate, including property ownership, land use controls, and state-specific regulations. Understanding these principles is essential for anyone entering the real estate field in Florida

This category includes the practical aspects of real estate, such as conducting transactions, managing brokerage activities, understanding and executing real estate contracts, securing residential mortgages, and handling computations and the closing of transactions. It focuses on the day-to-day operations and skills needed to successfully complete real estate deals.

This category covers the laws and regulations governing real estate practice. It includes license law and qualifications for licensure, commission rules, authorized relationships and duties, violations and penalties, federal and state laws, titles and deeds, and legal descriptions. It emphasizes understanding the legal requirements and ensuring compliance in real estate activities.

This category focuses on the analysis of property and market conditions. It includes understanding property rights, estates, tenancies, condominiums, cooperatives, community development districts, homeowner associations, and time-sharing. It also covers real estate markets and analysis, real estate appraisal, investments, taxes affecting real estate, and planning and zoning. It aims to provide insights into property values and market trends.

Choosing a Real Estate School

Selecting the right real estate school is crucial. Look for accredited schools that offer flexibility, especially if you have a busy schedule. Online courses can provide the convenience of studying at your own pace.

Research Schools

Start by researching various real estate schools and reading reviews from past students. Look for schools with high pass rates for the real estate exam and positive feedback on their teaching methods.

Online vs In-Person Classes

Decide whether you prefer online or in-person classes. Online courses offer flexibility and convenience, allowing you to study at your own pace. In-person classes provide direct interaction with instructors and peers, which can enhance your learning experience.

Evaluate Course Materials

Evaluate the course materials and support services provided by the school. High-quality textbooks, interactive lessons, and access to instructors for questions can significantly impact your success. Some schools also offer additional resources like exam prep courses and study groups.

Study Tips

Create a daily study schedule that covers all exam topics, ensuring regular review sessions. (Asana provides a great FREE task manager)

Utilize flashcards for key terms and concepts to enhance memorization. (These Quizlet Flashcards may be helpful)

Regularly take practice tests to gauge your understanding and get familiar with the exam format. (Free Florida Real Estate Practice Exam)

After completing your coursework, submit your license application to the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR)

Complete the Application Form: Fill out the DBPR RE 1 form available on the DBPR website. You can access the form here.

Gather Required Documents: Include proof of completed pre-licensing education and identification documents.

Schedule Fingerprinting: Use an approved Livescan service provider to complete your background check. You can find a list of providers here (Find the link to the list in the bottom section titled “List of Registered Livescan Service Providers”)

Submit Your Application: Mail or submit your application online through the DBPR’s online services portal.

The DBPR will take several weeks to process your application. During this time, they will review your transcripts and verify that you meet all the requirements. Make sure to double-check your application for completeness to avoid any delays.

You can track the status of your application online through the DBPR’s website. Regularly checking the status can help you stay informed about any issues or additional requirements. If there are delays, contacting the DBPR directly can provide clarity and expedite the process.

The exam is a 3.5-hour test with 100 multiple-choice questions. You need to score at least 75% to pass. Each attempt requires a new application and a fee of $37.

According to PrepAgent

  • The real estate business (1%)
  • Real Estate Brokerage Activities and Procedures (12%)
  • Real Estate Contracts (12%)
  • Residential Mortgages (9%)
  • Real Estate Related Computations and Closing of Transactions (6%)
  • License Law and Qualifications for Licensure (6%)
  • Real Estate License Law and Commission Rules (2%)
  • Authorized Relationships, Duties and Disclosures (7%)
  • Violations of License Law, Penalties and Procedures (2%)
  • Federal and State Laws Pertaining to Real Estate (4%)
  • Titles, Deeds, and Ownership Restrictions (7%)
  • Legal Descriptions (5%)
  • Property Rights: Estates, Tenancies; Condominiums, Cooperatives, Community Development Districts, Homeowner Associations, and Time-Sharing (8%)
  • Real Estate Markets and Analysis (1%)
  • Real Estate Appraisal (8%)
  • Real Estate Investments and Business Opportunity Brokerage (2%)
  • Taxes Affecting Real Estate (3%)
  • Planning and Zoning (1%)

Exam Preparation Tips

Go over the textbooks and notes from your pre-license courses. Revisiting these materials can reinforce your understanding of key concepts. Focus on areas where you feel less confident to ensure a well-rounded preparation.

Take as many practice exams as possible. This helps you get familiar with the exam format and identify areas where you need more study. Practice exams can also help you manage your time effectively during the actual test. (Free Florida Real Estate Practice Exam)

Join or form study groups. Discussing topics with peers can enhance understanding and retention. Study groups provide a platform to share knowledge, ask questions, and support each other.

Consider enrolling in an exam prep course for additional support and structured study. These courses often include practice exams, study guides, and expert instruction. Investing in a prep course can increase your chances of passing the exam on the first attempt.

Exam Day Tips

Ensure you arrive at the exam center early to avoid any last-minute stress. Arriving early gives you time to settle in and focus before the exam begins. Check the location and travel time in advance to plan your journey.

You’ll need a valid photo ID to enter the exam. Make sure your ID is current and matches the name on your application. Having all necessary documents ready can prevent any issues at the exam center.

Read each question carefully and manage your time wisely. Staying calm and composed can help you think clearly and avoid mistakes. Take deep breaths and stay positive throughout the exam.

Follow all instructions given by the exam proctors. Adhering to the rules ensures a smooth and fair testing experience for everyone. If you have any questions or issues, ask the proctors for assistance.

After passing the exam, you must complete a fingerprinting requirement for a background check. This is a mandatory step to ensure you meet the honesty and integrity standards set by the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR).

Use a Live Scan service provider approved by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE). Live Scan is an electronic fingerprinting process that is fast and secure. Locate a service provider near you and schedule an appointment (You can get this done for around $50-$80)

Fill out and submit the appropriate form along with the fingerprinting fee. The Live Scan service provider will electronically transmit your fingerprints to the FDLE. Keep a copy of the form and receipt for your records.

Be prepared to pay the fingerprinting fee, which varies by provider. The fee typically includes the cost of the Live Scan service and the background check. Confirm the total cost when scheduling your appointment.

The DBPR will conduct a background check using your fingerprints. This check ensures you meet the honesty and integrity standards required for a real estate license. Any issues identified during the background check may need to be addressed before your license is granted.

If any issues arise during the background check, be prepared to provide additional documentation or explanations. Demonstrating honesty and taking responsibility for past actions can positively impact the DBPR’s decision. Seek legal advice if necessary to navigate any complex issues.

The next step is to submit the Salesperson License Application. This application confirms that you have passed the exam and completed the fingerprinting requirement.

Form: Fill out the DBPR RE 1 form available on the DBPR website. Ensure all sections are completed accurately. You can access the form here.

Include proof that you passed the exam. This documentation is crucial for the DBPR to verify your eligibility. Keep a copy of your exam results for your records.

Attach your Live Scan Service form. This proof confirms that you have completed the fingerprinting requirement. Ensure all necessary signatures and details are included.

As of 2023, the fee is $83.75. This fee must be submitted along with your application. Keep a copy of your payment receipt for future reference.

After submitting your application, you can track its status online through the DRE’s website. Regularly checking the status can help you stay informed about any updates or additional requirements. If there are delays, contacting the DRE directly can provide clarity and expedite the process.

Find a Sponsoring Broker

Once you pass the exam, you need to find a sponsoring broker to activate your license. Look for a brokerage that aligns with your goals and offers the support you need.

What to Look For in a Broker

Find a supportive and collaborative environment. The right culture can significantly impact your job satisfaction and success.

Understand the financial arrangements. Different brokerages offer different commission splits, so choose one that suits your financial goals.

Choose a broker who provides ample training and mentorship opportunities. Early career support is crucial for your development and success.

17 Brokerage Interview Questions

  • What training programs do you offer for new agents?
  • How does your commission split work, and are there any additional fees?
  • What kind of support and resources will I have access to?
  • Can you provide references from other agents in your brokerage?

Top Brokerages to Consider

Choosing the right broker is crucial as it impacts your early career significantly. Consider top-rated brokers like eXp Realty, Keller Williams, Coldwell Banker, and Compass.

Why Join Smart Agent Alliance?

When you join Smart Agent Alliance, you get double the value because you’re also automatically a Wolf Pack member.  Together, Smart Agent Alliance and the Wolf Pack provide the tools, support, and expertise to elevate your business to new heights.

Smart Agent Alliance Benefits

At Smart Agent Alliance, we prioritize organization, clarity, and efficiency to help our agents succeed. We provide essential onboarding resources, customizable presentations, business automations, client checklists, business assets, social media content, YouTube support, a growth plan, quality lead generation, production know-how, website support, and top-notch organizational tools.

Wolf Pack Benefits

The Wolf Pack team at eXp Realty offers expert-led courses like Social Agent Academy 3.0, the Wolf Pack Hub, and the Investor Army for property flipping. We provide tailored assistance for new agents, developing agents, top producers, team leaders, and broker owners. Key resources include lead generation, production know-how, social media content, and YouTube support.

Why eXp Realty?

eXp Realty offers a comprehensive range of benefits for agents, focusing on top pay structures, low fees, and free stock options. Agents get an 80/20 commission splits that cap at $16,000 annually, with opportunities to earn 100% commission, receive annual stock awards and gain income through Revenue Share. Additional resources include 24/7 agent support, affordable healthcare, live training, and advanced tech tools like kvCORE and customizable IDX websites.

Starting a career in real estate involves some initial costs and financial planning. Understanding these costs and planning accordingly will help you manage your finances effectively.

Initial Expenses Breakdown

All stated fees are subject to change

  • Initial Expenses: These include licensing fees, marketing expenses, office supplies, and technology tools needed to start your career. For example, initial expenses may include:
    • Pre-Licensing Course: $100-$500
    • Exam Fee: $36.75 per attempt
    • Application Fee: $83.75
    • Fingerprinting Fee: Roughly $50-$80
    • Marketing Materials: Business cards, signage, and online advertising costs
  • Once you join a brokerage in Florida, many will require you to become a member of the National, State, and Local Associations of Realtors. Additionally, you’ll encounter fees for the Multiple Listing Service (MLS) and Supra Key services.
    • National Association of Realtors (NAR):
      • Membership Fees: For 2024, the annual dues for NAR are $156, plus a $45 special assessment fee for the Consumer Advertising Campaign, totaling $201 per year.
    • Florida Association of Realtors (FAR):
      • Membership Fees: The Florida Association of Realtors’ dues for 2024 are generally around $180 annually. This fee is separate from the NAR dues.
    • Local Association of Realtors:
      • Membership Fees: Local association fees in Florida can vary based on the specific association you join. For example:
      • Orlando Regional Realtor Association (ORRA): The annual dues are approximately $250 to $300.
      • Miami Association of Realtors: The dues range from $300 to $400 per year.
    • Multiple Listing Service (MLS):
      • Fees: MLS fees in Florida also vary depending on the region. For instance, the Miami MLS charges around $500 annually, while the Orlando MLS might charge closer to $300 per year.
    • Supra Key Fees:
      • Fees: In Florida, Supra Key services typically include an initial setup fee, which is around $50, and a monthly or annual service fee, costing about $20 to $25 per month.

These fees are approximate and can vary slightly depending on your location and the specific associations or MLS you join. It’s always best to confirm with your local associations or MLS for the most current and accurate fee information.

  • Create a Budget: Track your expenses and forecast your income. Plan for slower months to ensure financial stability.
  • Emergency Fund: Set aside an emergency fund to cover unexpected expenses or slow periods in the market
  • Commission Structure: Real estate agents typically earn commissions from sales. Understand how your brokerage’s commission structure works and how to manage irregular income streams. Commission splits can vary widely, typically ranging from 50/50 to 70/30 or higher, depending on the brokerage.
  • Tax Planning: As an independent contractor, it’s important to plan for taxes. Keep track of deductible expenses, make estimated tax payments, and maintain good record-keeping practices. Consulting with a tax professional can help ensure compliance and optimize your tax strategy.

To get a Florida real estate license, you must be at least 18 years old, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and complete 63 hours of approved pre-licensing education. Additionally, you must pass the state licensing exam and submit fingerprints for a background check.

The cost to get a real estate license in Florida typically ranges from $325 to $1,000. This includes the pre-licensing course ($100-$600), application fee ($83.75), background check fee ($50-$80), and exam fee ($36.75)

Getting a real estate license in Florida typically takes 2 to 5 months. This timeframe includes completing 63 hours of pre-licensing education, submitting the application and fingerprints, and passing the state exam, with application processing taking about 30 days.

The pass rate for the Florida real estate exam is 75% or higher. Proper preparation, including practice exams and study groups, can significantly improve your chances of passing.

What happens if I fail the real estate exam?

If you fail the Florida real estate exam, you can retake it as many times as necessary. You must wait 24 hours before rescheduling your exam and pay the exam fee of for each attempt.

To renew your Florida real estate license, you must complete 14 hours of Continuing Education, including 3 hours of Core Law and 3 hours of Ethics and Business Practices. Then, visit the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) website to submit your renewal application and pay the renewal fee.

title: Best Online Real Estate Schools in Florida
excerpt: Choosing one of the best online real estate schools in Florida is crucial for your career, and it’s important to thoroughly research your options and…
content:
Choosing one of the best online real estate schools in Florida is crucial for your career, and it’s important to thoroughly research your options and understand what each course offers. While there are countless real estate schools available, only a select few stand out for their exceptional education and comprehensive support in preparing you to obtain your real estate license.

At Smart Agent Alliance, we are committed to guiding new agents in launching successful careers. That’s why we’ve curated a list of the leading online real estate schools in Florida. Our detailed analysis covers the offerings of each school, their course delivery methods, and a balanced view of the advantages and disadvantages of studying with each one.

  1. AceableAgent
  2. The CE Shop
  3. Colibri Real Estate
  4. RealEstateU
  5. 360 Training

AceableAgent

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A+
Top Feature: Ability to study on the go with the mobile app

Why We Chose It:

AceableAgent has quickly become a favorite among students due to its modern approach and flexibility. It is exclusively focused on real estate education, offering courses for every step of a real estate career, from pre-licensing to continuing education and career advancement. The courses are state-approved and designed to be accessible from any device, providing students with the flexibility to study anywhere.

Overview:

AceableAgent offers three pre-licensing packages, all of which include the required coursework. The courses are fully online and accessible via desktop, laptop, tablet, or smartphone. This accessibility is one of AceableAgent’s standout features, allowing students to study on the go. Courses are developed by experienced professionals and are accredited by ARELLO. Additionally, AceableAgent is known for its interactive coursework, which helps students grasp and retain information effectively.

Why AceableAgent is Great for Pre-Licensing:

AceableAgent’s pre-licensing courses are available in multiple states, ensuring they meet state-specific requirements. The courses include engaging video lectures, interactive content, and practice exams to help students prepare effectively for their licensing exams. AceableAgent offers a satisfaction guarantee and provides career resources to help new agents start their careers successfully.

User Experiences and Feedback:

Students have reported that AceableAgent’s courses are particularly user-friendly, with a modern interface that makes navigation easy. The mobile app is highly rated for its convenience, allowing users to study during commutes or breaks. The interactive content, including quizzes and video explanations, has been praised for making complex topics easier to understand. Additionally, AceableAgent’s customer service, though sometimes slow, is generally helpful and responsive to student needs.

Pre-Licensing

Price Starts at: $149
Basic Package Features: The AceableAgent 63-Hour Course includes instructor support via email; fully narrated courses with audio guides; Lite Exam Prep with 1,000 unique practice questions; a mini-course to help you find the right sponsoring broker as you start your real estate career.
Upgrade Packages: Yes, the upgraded packages offer 3 months of access, 75 videos, 70 audio lessons, and digital flashcards. It also includes 1,660+ practice questions, a 100+ page exam prep ebook, 1 hour of private tutoring, live webinars five times a week, and live Q&A sessions with expert tutors.

Exam Prep

Price Starts at: $59
Basic Package Features: Thousands of practice questions; 100% money-back guarantee; 75+ real estate exam prep videos; online interactive flashcards; 100+ page exam prep ebook; hours of audio lessons; interactive vocabulary worksheet; 100s of hours of recorded webinars; live online webinars.
Upgrade Packages: Yes, the upgraded packages offer access to PrepAgent for 1 or 2 months, compared to just 1 week with the basic plan.

Flexible Learning Options: Enjoy self-paced courses that fit your schedule.

Extended Course Access: Access course materials for up to six months from your enrollment date.

Risk-Free Enrollment: Benefit from a 30-day money-back guarantee if you’re not satisfied.

Exam Success Guarantee: Pass the licensing exam within three tries or receive a full course refund.

Comprehensive Exam Preparation: Gain access to a variety of study tools including prep videos, 75 audio lessons, digital flashcards, over 1600 practice questions, a 100-page exam prep ebook, weekly live webinars, live Q&A sessions with instructors, and the option for personalized 1-on-1 tutoring.

Dedicated Support: Instructor assistance is available seven days a week via email, and customer service can be reached by email and phone from Monday to Friday.

Convenient Final Exams: Utilize online proctoring services for the final exam across the nation, although California students do not need a proctor for their pre-licensing exam.

Mobile-Friendly Platform: Study anytime, anywhere with a course platform that is fully optimized for mobile devices.

Interactive Learning Tools: Engage with interactive content designed to enhance your learning experience and retention.

Career Resources: Access additional career support services to help you transition from student to professional agent successfully.

Pros:

  • Mobile app for studying
  • High pass rates among schools with 1,000+ students
  • Engaging and entertaining course materials
  • Exam prep through PrepAgent

Cons:

  • Course access lasts for 12 months
  • Some bugs reported in the mobile app
  • Limited technical support
  • Outsourced exam proctoring

To view their current pricing for pre-licensing click this linked button. If you are interested in any of the other courses they offer, you can find that through this link as well.

The CE Shop

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Course is easy to follow, high pass rates among students

Why We Chose It: The CE Shop offers a variety of real estate education options with an interactive and inquiry-based approach in their studying methods. While their focus is mainly on continuing education, they also provide excellent pre-licensing courses, exam prep, and post-licensing education. Their courses are accredited by ARELLO and have received numerous awards for their educational programs.

Overview: The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses can be taken in 34 states, through four different course packages: Courses Only, Standard Package, Value Package, and Premium Package. Every package comes with business ebooks, career resources, downloadable resources, real estate glossary, digital flashcards, study schedules, and access to instructor-led webinars. Students have praised the course content for being easy to follow and highly informative, which has led to high pass rates.

Why The CE Shop is Great for Pre-Licensing: The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses emphasize real-world applications with scenario-based learning. This approach helps students apply their knowledge to practical situations they will face in their real estate careers. Additionally, The CE Shop provides an exam prep edge program that offers additional practice tests and study aids to ensure students are well-prepared for their licensing exams.

User Experiences and Feedback: The CE Shop is well-regarded for its robust customer support and comprehensive resources. The ability to access instructor-led webinars provides an additional layer of support and interaction, which can be particularly beneficial for students who need more guidance. The frequent promotions and discounts make it a cost-effective option for many. Students appreciate the clear and structured study schedules, which help them stay on track and complete the course efficiently.

Pre-Licensing

Price Starts at: $111.20

Basic Package Features: This package includes the 63-Hour FL Real Estate Sales Associate Licensing Course, which prepares you for the Florida state licensing exam and equips you with the essential business knowledge to succeed as a real estate salesperson in Florida.

Upgrade Packages: The Premium Package includes the eTextbook *Real Estate Basics and Beyond*, FL Exam Prep Edge, and your first license renewal package for free. Additionally, the 2024 Real Estate Success Builder program offers courses in performance improvement, time management, and market insights.

Exam Prep

Price Starts at: $101.25

Basic Package Features: Offers content based on the Florida Candidate Information Booklet, covers every topic for your licensing exam. Exam Prep Edge provides individual lessons by topic for efficient studying, with real-time gauges to track your readiness. We offer 7-day support through call, chat, or email for any questions.

Upgrade Packages: None

Post-Licensing

Price Starts at: $105

Basic Package Features: The Florida Post-Licensing package includes 45 hours of courses required for Sales Associate licensees in their first renewal cycle. These courses must be completed before the license’s first renewal expiration date and include 15 hours each in Business Planning, Finance & Economics, and Market Specialties.

Upgrade Packages: Yes, this package includes the ProPath Real Estate Business Builder program, covering Pricing Strategies, Tax Planning for the Self-Employed, and Budgeting to Build Your Business.

Continuing Education

Price Starts at: $39

Basic Package Features: This package provides all 14 hours needed for active license renewals, including Florida Core Law (3 hours), Document Diligence: Safeguarding Your Transactions (4 hours), Using the Code to Solve Ethical Dilemmas (3 hours), and Assistance Animals and Fair Housing (4 hours).

Upgrade Packages: Yes, this package includes all 14 hours needed for Florida real estate license renewal and the ProPath Network Builder program, which focuses on enhancing your networking skills, creating value propositions, and building long-term business relationships to boost your real estate career.

Learning Format: Flexible, self-paced online courses.

Access Duration: Six months from the start date.

Money-Back Guarantee: Full refund within 30 days if less than 50% of the course is completed.

Pass Assurance: Exam cost reimbursed if you don’t pass on the first attempt.

Exam Preparation: Targeted review sessions, custom study plans, unlimited practice tests, and live webinars.

Support Services: Available daily via email, phone, or chat.

Final Exam Procedure: Online proctoring available nationwide; California exams are administered by the DRE at specific centers.

Extra Resources: Includes digital flashcards, a real estate glossary, a study schedule, business courses, and state-specific content.

Pros:

  • Multiple study package options and monthly payment plans
  • High pass rates among students
  • Interactive and easy-to-follow course material
  • Frequent discounts and promotions

Cons:

  • Mainly text-based study materials
  • Some students find the materials take longer to complete than expected
  • Limited coverage of real estate math

To view their current pricing for pre-licensing, first click this linked button, then under the main heading select “Real Estate” then fill in your State, Education, and License type (Your State, Pre-Licencing, Sales-Licencing)

Colibri Real Estate

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Affordable and comprehensive study materials

Why We Chose It: Colibri Real Estate is known for its affordability and thorough course materials. It provides excellent support to students preparing for their exams and offers a range of courses that cater to different learning needs. Colibri’s courses are designed to be clear and easy to understand, making them a great choice for budget-conscious students.

Overview: Colibri Real Estate offers various online courses with comprehensive study materials. The courses are designed to prepare students effectively for their licensing exams, with detailed support and resources. The pricing is competitive, making it an accessible option for many students.

Why Colibri Real Estate is Great for Pre-Licensing: Colibri Real Estate’ pre-licensing courses include interactive study tools such as flashcards, practice tests, and exam simulators. The courses are state-approved and designed to meet all the requirements for licensure. Colibri also offers a “pass or don’t pay” guarantee, ensuring students can retake the course if they don’t pass the exam on the first try. They also provide a career starter guide to help new agents transition smoothly into their real estate careers.

User Experiences and Feedback: Colibri Real Estate has a strong reputation for providing value for money. The comprehensive study materials are frequently updated to reflect the latest industry standards and practices. Students have noted that the detailed exam preparation support, including practice exams and study guides, is particularly helpful for passing the state licensing exams. The school’s customer support, though sometimes slow, is knowledgeable and helpful in resolving issues.

Pre-Licensing

Price Starts at: $88.20
Basic Package Features: The Pre-License Course covers the state-required 63 hours, offering flexible audio learning and access to local experts. Retain key concepts with three e-books: “Fearless Math,” “Quick Start Guide,” and the course manual.
Upgrade Packages: CompuCram Exam Prep, included in The Career Essentials and Ultimate packages, offers flashcards, dynamic feedback, unlimited practice tests, and simulated exams. It’s mobile-friendly and includes live Exam Crammer webinars, audible course summaries, a 1-year Career Booster Pack, and a course textbook.

Exam Prep

Price Starts at: $69
Basic Package Features: Exam Prep with audio playback lets you review key topics on the go. If you don’t pass on the first try, you get a refund with the Pass or Don’t Pay Guarantee.
Upgrade Packages: Yes, their packages include 40 hours of live Q&A sessions, a 6-part Live Exam Crammer Series, and a Pass or Don’t Pay Guarantee (excludes FL, NJ, TN). The Post-License Course is self-paced, letting you complete required education on your schedule.

Post-Licensing

Price Starts at: $87.20
Basic Package Features: The 45-hour Post-License Course offers self-paced online learning with access to expert instructors. It includes a RISMedia Premier Membership and audio course materials.
Upgrade Packages: None

Continuing Education

Price Starts at: $87.20
Basic Package Features: The 45-hour Post-License Course is self-paced, allowing you to complete the required education online. It includes access to expert local instructors, RISMedia Premier Membership benefits, and an audio learning option for flexibility.
Upgrade Packages: None

Learning Options: Choose between self-paced online courses or live-streamed classes with real-time instructors for a classroom-like experience from home.

Course Access: Six months of access from the enrollment date.

Refund Policy: Full refund for self-paced courses if canceled within 30 days, and within 24 hours for live-stream courses.

Pass Guarantee: For packages with exam prep, Colibri will refund the course cost if you score 80% or higher on simulated exams but don’t pass the state exam on the first try.

Exam Preparation: Includes digital flashcards, mock exams, readiness assessments, audio review guides, live Q&A sessions, and six one-hour live webinars with instructors for focused preparation.

Instructor Support: Available by phone during business hours or via email for additional assistance.

Final Exam Process: Virtual proctoring available nationwide; in California, the DRE administers the exam at designated centers.

Additional Resources: Access to state-specific pre-licensing, continuing education, broker licensing, and mortgage licensing courses, as well as practice exams and a real estate dictionary.

Pros:

  • Affordable courses
  • Comprehensive study materials
  • Detailed exam preparation support

Cons:

  • Limited interactivity in course materials
  • Some students found customer support to be slow

To view their current pricing, click this linked button, then select your desired State, Education Selection, and Education Option Selection.

RealEstateU

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A-
Top Feature: Best affordable courses available

Why We Chose It: RealEstateU is known for its affordability and straightforward approach to real estate education. The audio-based courses are perfect for students who prefer to study on the go. The courses are designed to be simple yet effective, making them an excellent choice for budget-conscious students.

Overview: RealEstateU offers audio lectures that can be accessed on a computer, smartphone, or tablet. The courses are divided into chapters with related key terms, infographics, and quizzes to reinforce learning. Students can take the final exam online and receive a certificate of completion upon passing. The courses are highly affordable, often available at discounted rates.

Why RealEstateU is Great for Pre-Licensing: RealEstateU’s pre-licensing courses are tailored for various states, ensuring compliance with state-specific regulations. The audio-based format is ideal for students who prefer auditory learning, and the courses are designed to be flexible and convenient. RealEstateU also offers an online exam prep course to help students prepare for their licensing exam and includes a detailed course completion timeline to keep students on track.

User Experiences and Feedback: RealEstateU’s unique audio-based approach allows students to study hands-free, making it convenient for those with busy schedules. The courses are structured to be easy to follow, with clear explanations and relevant examples. Students appreciate the flexibility to listen to lectures while commuting or during other activities. The affordable pricing, coupled with frequent discounts, makes RealEstateU an attractive option for many.

Our Review Process:

At SmartAgentAlliance, our goal is to provide accurate and helpful reviews of online real estate schools to assist prospective real estate agents in making informed decisions. Our review process involves several key steps:

Research and Data Collection:

We begin by gathering comprehensive information about each real estate school, including course offerings, pricing, accreditation, and user reviews. This involves visiting the schools’ websites, reading third-party reviews, and gathering feedback from current and former students.

Evaluation Criteria:

Our evaluation is based on several important criteria, including:

  • Course Quality: We assess the content and structure of the courses to ensure they cover all necessary topics comprehensively and are easy to follow.
  • Accessibility: We evaluate the flexibility and accessibility of the courses, including the availability of mobile apps and study materials.
  • Pass Rates: We consider the pass rates of students who have completed the courses and taken the licensing exam.
  • Student Support: We look at the level of support provided to students, including access to instructors, customer service, and additional resources like study guides and practice exams.
  • Pricing: We compare the cost of the courses relative to the value they offer, including any discounts or payment plans available.
  • User Feedback: We gather and analyze feedback from students who have taken the courses to get an understanding of their experiences and satisfaction levels.

Scoring and Ranking:

Each school is scored based on the evaluation criteria, and an overall score is calculated. The scores are then used to rank the schools, with additional considerations given to standout features that may set a school apart from the rest.

content:
This article will provide a comprehensive comparison between Compass vs Sotheby’s to help you determine which brokerage better aligns with your professional goals. Choosing the right brokerage is a critical decision for any real estate agent, as it significantly impacts their career trajectory and financial success.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Compass vs Sotheby’s
Join Our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

The commission splits and associated fees are crucial factors to consider when selecting a brokerage. Compass offers splits ranging from 60/40 to 92.5/7.5, with a no franchise/royalty fee, and some agents get a cap. Sotheby’s provides splits starting at 70/30 and going up to 90/10, also with a 6% franchise/royalty fee, and no cap.

Monthly fees also differ significantly. Compass charges $145, varying by office, whereas Sotheby’s monthly fees also vary by office. Additionally, Compass charges transaction fees up to 4%, while Sotheby’s includes transaction fees within their royalty fees. These differences can impact an agent’s net income and financial planning, making it important to consider each brokerage’s fee structure.

Income Opportunities

The potential for additional income streams can significantly enhance an agent’s financial stability and growth. Unfortunately, neither Compass nor Sotheby’s offers revenue share programs, retirement income paths, or willable income paths, limiting agents primarily to their commission-based earnings.

Training and Support

Effective training and support are vital for both new and experienced agents. Compass offers training through Compass Academy, providing structured learning opportunities. In contrast, Sotheby’s provides training that varies by office, which might lead to inconsistencies in the quality of training received. Neither brokerage offers 24/7 support, which can be crucial for agents who require ongoing assistance and professional development.

Technology and Resources

In the modern real estate landscape, leveraging technology effectively is essential. Compass is recognized for its technological advancements and robust tools available through Compass Academy. Sotheby’s also incorporates technological tools, but its offerings vary by office. Both brokerages provide valuable technological resources, but the specific tools and platforms offered may appeal differently depending on the agent’s needs.

Agent Satisfaction

Agent satisfaction is a key indicator of a brokerage’s effectiveness and overall agent happiness. Compass has a Glassdoor rating of 3.7 stars based on 2.4K reviews, indicating areas needing improvement. Sotheby’s holds a slightly higher rating of 4.0 stars from 501 reviews, suggesting relatively higher agent satisfaction. The differences in agent satisfaction can often be attributed to the varying levels of support, training, and income opportunities provided by each brokerage.

Final Thoughts on Compass vs Sotheby’s

In comparing Compass and Sotheby’s, it’s evident that each brokerage has its strengths and weaknesses. Sotheby’s offers a more traditional structure with consistent fee inclusions, making it a stable choice for many agents. Compass, with its advanced technology and structured training through Compass Academy, appeals to those who prioritize continuous learning and modern tools.

For a more detailed comparison and to find the best brokerage for your needs, check out our brokerage comparison tool.

When making your decision, consider your specific needs and career objectives. Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages carefully to choose the brokerage that best fits your professional aspirations. Whether you prioritize comprehensive support and training or seek a brokerage with a more conventional setup, your decision should align with your long-term career goals and preferences.

Today, we’re comparing two big names in the real estate world—eXp Realty and Fathom Realty. Choosing the right brokerage sets the foundation for your success. Pick the right one, and you’re off to a great start. Pick the wrong one, and it’s tough to get moving. Here’s your handy-dandy index:

Frequently Asked Questions

Why Your Brokerage Choice Matters

Your choice of brokerage impacts far more than just your paycheck. It defines your entire real estate career. Sure, commission splits are a major factor, but the resources, training, support, and even the day-to-day experience you’ll have as an agent are just as important.

Picking the right brokerage means finding the one that best fits your style, goals, and needs—while also helping you maximize your income.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Overview

Fathom Realty and eXp Realty are cloud-based brokerages without physical office space. However, for those agents who desire to work outside their homes or to have a place to meet with clients, eXp Realty does offer FREE access to over 4,000 Regus office business lounges worldwide.

Both Fathom Realty and eXp Realty are looking to provide agents with better splits as neither pays out agent earnings to layers of franchise owners. To understand more about that, check out the eXp Explained video found here.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Agent Satisfaction

A key way to gauge how happy you’ll be at a brokerage is by checking out agent satisfaction. According to Glassdoor, eXp Realty holds a 4.6-star rating from over 3,500 reviews, while Fathom Realty also boasts a 4.6-star rating, but from just 425 reviews.

However, eXp Realty consistently ranks on Glassdoor’s Top 100 Companies list from 2018 to 2024, while Fathom Realty hasn’t made an appearance on that list. That consistent recognition speaks volumes about the agent experience and satisfaction at eXp Realty.

If you’re curious about how the top real estate firms stack up, check out our blog “12 Insider Picks for the Best Real Estate Brokerage in 2024!” Spoiler alert: eXp Realty ranks #1 on Glassdoor.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Brokerage Availability

Another critical consideration is where these brokerages operate. eXp Realty spans 50 states and 24 countries with a robust agent network of over 80,000 agents. This broad reach provides agents with unmatched opportunities to collaborate and grow globally.

In contrast, Fathom Realty operates in 41 states and 5 countries, with an agent count exceeding 11,000. While Fathom has a solid presence, eXp Realty’s broader global reach and larger network offer agents a far wider range of opportunities, resources, and potential for referrals—an important factor when choosing between eXp Realty and Fathom Realty.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Brokerage Profitability

Why does profitability matter? Because a financially stable brokerage can keep offering you great tools, training, and support without cutting corners. When a brokerage is in the red, agents often feel the pinch.

Fathom Realty has posted 19 quarters of earnings, but with only 1 profitable quarter. That’s a tough track record to overlook as it’s unclear if Fathom will survive especially now that the real estate business is changing due to the new NAR rules. On the other hand, eXp Realty has posted 20 quarters of earnings, with 15 profitable quarters, putting them at 75% profitability.

More importantly, eXp Realty is the only publicly traded brokerage that’s been profitable for the past five years. That kind of stability means continued improvements for agents and clients, with no surprises or cost-cutting measures that might hurt your bottom line.

If you want the full scoop on brokerage profitability, check out our blog “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Commission Splits

When it comes to commission splits, this is where agents usually focus most of their attention—it determines how much of your hard-earned commission stays in your pocket.

Fathom Realty is a 100% commission brokerage, meaning you keep all of your commission, but you pay various transaction fees depending on the size of the sale. Fathom also offers a recruiting income model similar to revenue share, but it requires you to join one of their paid plans, and commissions are only earned from producing agents. The Cap4Life program is another path to reduce fees long term, but it has a steep qualification threshold.

At eXp Realty, agents start with an 80/20 split, and once you’ve paid $16,000 to the brokerage for the year, you cap and move to 100% commission. Plus, eXp rewards agents with stock for hitting certain milestones, and you can even get your $16,000 cap back in company stock.

Bottom line: eXp agents can earn more than 100% of their commission while getting all the other benefits that only eXp Realty offers.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: E&O Insurance

Errors and Omissions (E&O) insurance is critical for protecting you and your brokerage from potential legal claims. At Fathom Realty, agents pay $0 in upfront E&O insurance, but there is a $35 per transaction fee and no cap.

Meanwhile, at eXp Realty, agents pay $60 per transaction. Plus, once you hit $750 for the year, you’re capped and done paying for E&O.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Fees

Next up, let’s talk fees, because no one wants to be surprised by extra costs eating into their earnings.

Fathom Realty charges $99 to join and has a $550 fee for your first 15 sales under $600K. For deals over $600K, there are additional fees: $200 for sales up to $1 million, and another $250 for every additional $500K. At eXp Realty, agents pay an $85 monthly fee and a $25 transaction fee per deal until they hit their cap.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Training and Support

Whether you’re new or a seasoned pro, training and support are key to growing your business.

eXp Realty offers over 50 live training sessions every week, along with an extensive on-demand library full of resources. New agents can jump into the Fast Start program to get up and running quickly, while more experienced agents can take advantage of the Kick Start program to keep leveling up.

And with 24/7 support and over 2,000 full-time staff members, you’ll never be left without help when you need it.

On the other hand, Fathom Realty offers limited live training hours. It’s also unknown how much support is available at Fathom, so be sure to check when you interview there.

eXp Realty vs. Fathom: Technology and Resources

Staying ahead of the game requires the right tools, and eXp Realty excels in this area. As a fully virtual brokerage, eXp agents can do everything online, from meeting with their broker to attending training sessions.

The eXp World platform is a metaverse for agents, allowing them to collaborate and work together in real time. Only eXp World has this amazing feature for agents! Want to know more? Check out our blog on eXp World!

eXp Realty also provides each agent with their own IDX website, a powerful kvCORE CRM, and a marketing center filled with customizable templates for social media, flyers, and more.

Fathom Realty’s technology and resources are less well-known. There isn’t much information available about what tech tools they provide to agents.

eXp’s Exclusive Resources

Beyond the usual offerings, eXp Realty has a few game-changing features that other brokerages simply don’t provide. eXp Realty has a luxury division with global advertising around the world. eXp Realty has a dedicated team, Revenos, whose entire mission is to find and deliver top-quality leads directly to eXp agents—how great is that?

Then there’s eXp’s Referral tool that makes sending referrals to other agents effortless, and for those wanting to focus purely on referrals, eXp’s Referral Division slashes costs while keeping you active in the industry.

And, of course, there’s Revenue Share, which lets you build extra income by bringing other agents into eXp. Revenue Share opportunities at eXp can’t be beat. The best part? That income doesn’t end when you retire and it’s willable, so it continues to roll in even after you’re no longer working. Learn more about the amazing opportunity for revenue share income from our blog here.

The bottom line is that because eXp Realty is uniquely profitable, eXp continues to innovate and provide more exclusive resources helping agents and their clients. eXp Realty works hard to maintain its tag line as the most agent-centric brokerage on the planet.

That’s a Wrap

When comparing eXp Realty to Fathom Realty, it’s clear that eXp Realty stands out with its transparent commission splits, lower fees, and unparalleled support and technology. Fathom Realty is a solid choice for agents who prefer the 100% commission model, but when it comes to overall value and income opportunities, eXp Realty has the upper hand.

What makes eXp Realty different?

Besides top agent pay, low fees, extensive training, and state-of-the-art technology, eXp has a Luxury Division offering global marketing, a dedicated team called Revenos providing quality leads to agents, a Referral tool making referrals to other agents a breeze, a Referral Division cutting agent costs for referral only business and Revenue Share opportunities providing additional agent income possibilities that continue after retirement and is willable.

Today, we’re putting two heavyweights in the real estate industry head-to-head—eXp Realty and LPT Realty. Choosing the right brokerage can set the stage for your entire career. Pick the right one, and you’re on a solid path to success.

Pick the wrong one, and your momentum might stall before it even begins. So, let’s break down both brokerages to see which could be a better fit for your needs. Here’s your handy dandy index:

Frequently Asked Questions

Why Your Brokerage Choice Matters

Your brokerage choice is about so much more than just commission splits. Sure, the paycheck matters, but the resources, training, support, and the day-to-day experience you’ll have as an agent are crucial too. Picking the right brokerage means finding one that suits your style, your goals, and gives you the tools to maximize your income and build a successful career.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Overview

Both LPT Realty and eXp Realty are cloud-based brokerages with no brick-and-mortar office spaces, making them both flexible options for agents.

However, if you’re an agent who prefers having a place to work outside your home or wants a professional setting to meet with clients, eXp Realty offers FREE access to over 4,000 Regus office business lounges worldwide. This access gives eXp agents an additional edge when it comes to meeting clients or collaborating with other professionals in a formal environment.

Both brokerages are designed to provide agents with better commission splits by avoiding franchise owners’ layers, allowing more money to go into the agents’ pockets. To understand more about that, check out the eXp Explained video found here.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Agent Satisfaction

One key indicator of what your experience might be like at a brokerage is to check out agent satisfaction. On Glassdoor, eXp Realty holds an impressive 4.6-star rating from over 3,500 reviews, while LPT Realty comes in slightly lower with a 4.3-star rating from just 37 reviews.

Notably, eXp Realty has consistently made it onto Glassdoor’s Top 100 Companies list from 2018 to 2024, a level of recognition LPT Realty has yet to achieve. The consistency of eXp’s recognition highlights a strong track record of agent satisfaction and support.

If you’re curious about how the top real estate firms stack up, check out our blog “12 Insider Picks for the Best Real Estate Brokerage in 2024!” Spoiler alert: eXp Realty ranks #1 on Glassdoor.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Brokerage Availability

Another big factor when choosing a brokerage is where they operate. eXp Realty spans 50 states and 24 countries, with a powerful agent network of over 80,000 agents. This broad reach offers unmatched opportunities for agents to collaborate globally, expand their client base, and build referral relationships around the world.

By contrast, LPT Realty currently operates in 31 states, with an agent count exceeding 4,500. While LPT Realty is growing, it doesn’t yet match the global presence and network size of eXp Realty. If you’re looking for a broader reach and more expansive resources, eXp Realty’s global network offers more opportunities for collaboration and income generation.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Brokerage Profitability

Why does profitability matter to you as an agent? A financially stable brokerage can continue investing in tools, training, and support for its agents. When brokerages struggle financially, they may cut back on resources or start implementing fees that hurt your bottom line.

LPT Realty does not currently have listed stock, so it’s difficult to know how profitable or unprofitable the company is. For new agents, this might raise questions about long-term financial stability.

On the other hand, eXp Realty has posted 20 quarters of earnings with 15 profitable quarters, which means 75% profitability. Additionally, eXp Realty is the only publicly traded brokerage that has been profitable for the last five years, which signals continued stability and growth.

If you want the full scoop on brokerage profitability, check out our blog “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Commission Splits

Let’s get into what most agents care about most—commission splits. LPT Realty offers a 100% commission model for agents unless they choose to participate in the company’s Revenue Share Partner program. In that case, agents work on an 80/20 split until they hit their $15,000 cap, after which they keep 100% of their commissions.

At eXp Realty, agents start with an 80/20 split, and once you’ve paid $16,000 to the brokerage for the year, you move to 100% commission.

But here’s the kicker—eXp Realty rewards agents with company stock for hitting certain production milestones, and if you meet additional goals, you can earn your $16,000 cap back in stock. This means eXp agents can earn more than 100% of their commission, all while enjoying top-tier benefits that eXp offers its agents across the board.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Fees

When it comes to fees, let’s look at what both brokerages charge.

At LPT Realty, agents pay a $500 annual fee on their first sale. Agents then have two monthly fee options: $89 per month for standard agents or $149 per month for Revenue Share Partners. On top of that, there’s a $195 transaction fee per deal.

At eXp Realty, agents pay an $85 monthly fee and a $25 transaction fee per deal until they cap. The straightforward nature of eXp’s fees makes it easier for agents to plan their expenses and know exactly where their money is going.

At eXp Realty, agents pay $60 for E&O insurance per transaction. Once you hit $750 for the year, you’re capped and done paying for E&O, giving you peace of mind and saving you money in the long run. At LPT Realty, there is no upfront E&O insurance cost.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Training and Support

Training and support are critical factors in an agent’s success, no matter how experienced you are.

At eXp Realty, agents get access to over 50 live training sessions each week, plus an extensive on-demand library with courses and resources for every stage of your career. New agents can dive into the Fast Start program, designed to get them up and running quickly, while more seasoned agents can benefit from the Kick Start program to level up their business.

On top of that, eXp offers 24/7 support through over 2,000 full-time staff members, so you’re never left without help.

At LPT Realty, live training is more limited, and the amount of support agents get seems to vary depending on the office. If continuous professional development and on-demand support are must-haves for you, eXp Realty may be the stronger choice.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Technology and Resources

Technology is a key driver of success in today’s real estate world, and eXp Realty leads the way with its virtual-first approach. The entire company is based online, so agents can access everything—from training to support—via the eXp World platform.

It’s a metaverse-style environment where you can meet with brokers, collaborate with peers, and attend training sessions in real-time. Want more details? Check out our blog on eXp World!

In addition, eXp Realty provides agents with their own IDX website, a robust kvCORE CRM, and a marketing center full of customizable templates for social media, flyers, and more.

LPT Realty’s technology and resources aren’t as well-publicized, with no clear information on the tech tools they offer to their agents. Without details on what technology support is provided, it’s hard to compare the two, but eXp Realty’s extensive suite of tools is hard to beat.

eXp Realty vs. LPT Realty: Income Opportunities

When it comes to income opportunities, eXp Realty stands out with multiple revenue streams, including revenue share, stock production awards, and the ability to purchase discounted stock—all designed to help agents build long-term financial security. While LPT Realty also offers revenue share, it doesn’t provide stock options since it isn’t publicly listed.

Both brokerages offer revenue share programs, but there’s a key difference: At LPT Realty, agents must first meet their $15,000 cap before earning any revenue share that year, whereas eXp Realty has no such requirement—allowing agents to start earning from day one.

Additionally, eXp Realty’s revenue share pool is significantly larger, sitting at approximately $204 million, compared to $16 million at LPT Realty.

Another advantage for eXp Realty agents is the ability to offer unique value to attract other agents to their sponsor line, setting themselves apart with exclusive resources. LPT Realty agents don’t have this level of differentiation, as all sponsors offer the same resources.

This entrepreneurial flexibility gives eXp Realty agents a significant edge in recruiting and growing their revenue share. Learn more about eXp Realty’s amazing opportunity for revenue share income from our blog here.

eXp’s Exclusive Resources

Beyond the usual offerings, eXp Realty has a few game-changing features that other brokerages simply don’t provide. eXp Realty has a luxury division with global advertising around the world. eXp Realty has a dedicated team, Revenos, whose entire mission is to find and deliver top-quality leads directly to eXp agents—how great is that?

Then there’s eXp’s Referral tool that makes sending referrals to other agents effortless, and for those wanting to focus purely on referrals, eXp’s Referral Division slashes costs while keeping you active in the industry.

The bottom line is that because eXp Realty is uniquely profitable, eXp continues to innovate and provide more exclusive resources helping agents and their clients. eXp Realty works hard to maintain its tag line as the most agent-centric brokerage on the planet.

That’s a Wrap

LPT Realty and eXp Realty both offer cloud-based platforms and revenue share programs, but eXp Realty provides additional income opportunities through stock production awards and discounted stock. eXp Realty has no cap requirement for earning revenue share, while LPT Realty requires agents to meet a $15,000 cap first.

With more extensive training, support, and global reach, eXp Realty operates in 50 states and 24 countries, compared to LPT’s 41 states and 5 countries. Overall, eXp Realty stands out with broader income streams, a larger agent network, and superior agent resources.

Redfin has 20 quarters of earnings and a 15% profitability rate. eXp Realty has posted 20 quarters of earnings and a 75% profitability rate. For more on brokerage profitability, check out “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”.

What makes eXp Realty different?

Besides top agent pay, low fees, extensive training, and state-of-the-art technology, eXp has a Luxury Division offering global marketing,  a dedicated team called Revenos providing quality leads to agents, a Referral tool making referrals to other agents a breeze, a Referral Division cutting agent costs for referral only business and Revenue Share opportunities providing additional agent income possibilities that continue after retirement and is willable.

content:
This article will provide a comprehensive comparison between Compass vs Corcoran to help you determine which brokerage better aligns with your professional goals. Choosing the right brokerage is a critical decision for any real estate agent, as it significantly impacts their career trajectory and financial success.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Compass vs Corcoran
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

The commission splits and associated fees are crucial factors to consider when selecting a brokerage. Compass offers splits ranging from 60/40 to 92.5/7.5, with a no franchise/royalty fee. Corcoran provides splits starting at 50/50 and going up to 70/30, with a 6% franchise/royalty fee as well. Furthermore, Coompass does technically have a production cap, though not always, this gets a bit murky, Corcoran on the other hand doesnt at all.

Monthly fees also differ significantly. Compass charges $145, varying by office, whereas Corcoran’s fees also vary by office but include the franchise fee within their royalty fees. Additionally, Compass charges transaction fees up to 4%, while Corcoran includes transaction fees within their royalty fees. These differences can impact an agent’s net income and financial planning, making it important to consider each brokerage’s fee structure.

Income Opportunities

The potential for additional income streams can significantly enhance an agent’s financial stability and growth. Unfortunately, neither Compass nor Corcoran offers revenue share programs, retirement income paths, or willable income paths, limiting agents primarily to their commission-based earnings.

Training and Support

Effective training and support are vital for both new and experienced agents. Compass offers training through Compass Academy, providing structured learning opportunities. In contrast, Corcoran provides training that varies by office, which might lead to inconsistencies in the quality of training received. Neither brokerage offers 24/7 support, which can be crucial for agents who require ongoing assistance and professional development.

Technology and Resources

In the modern real estate landscape, leveraging technology effectively is essential. Compass is recognized for its technological advancements and robust tools available through Compass Academy. On the other hand, Corcoran, while incorporating some technological tools, still focuses heavily on traditional methods. Both brokerages provide valuable technological resources, but the specific tools and platforms offered may appeal differently depending on the agent’s needs.

Agent Satisfaction

Agent satisfaction is a key indicator of a brokerage’s effectiveness and overall agent happiness. Corcoran boasts a high Glassdoor rating of 4.4 stars based on 321 reviews, indicating strong agent approval and satisfaction. Compass holds a lower rating of 3.7 stars from 2.4K reviews, suggesting that there may be areas needing improvement. The differences in agent satisfaction can often be attributed to the varying levels of support, training, and income opportunities provided by each brokerage.

Final Thoughts on Compass vs Corcoran

In comparing Compass and Corcoran, it’s evident that each brokerage has its strengths and weaknesses. Corcoran offers a more consistent fee structure and higher agent satisfaction, making it a stable choice for many agents. Compass, with its advanced technology and structured training through Compass Academy, appeals to those who prioritize technological integration and continuous learning.

For a more detailed comparison and to find the best brokerage for your needs, check out our brokerage comparison tool.

When making your decision, consider your specific needs and career objectives. Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages carefully to choose the brokerage that best fits your professional aspirations. Whether you prioritize comprehensive support and training or seek a brokerage with a more conventional setup, your decision should align with your long-term career goals and preferences.

Today, we’re putting two of the most innovative names in the real estate industry head-to-head—eXp Realty and Real Broker. Choosing the right brokerage sets the foundation for your career success.

Pick the right one, and you’re on a solid path to growth. Pick the wrong one, and your momentum could stall. So, let’s break down both brokerages to see which might be the better fit for your needs. Here’s your handy dandy index:

Why Your Brokerage Choice Matters

Your brokerage choice is about more than just your commission split. Sure, the paycheck matters, but the resources, training, support, and the day-to-day experience you’ll have as an agent are equally crucial. Picking the right brokerage means finding one that aligns with your goals and gives you the tools to maximize your income and build a thriving career.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Overview

Both Real Broker and eXp Realty operate as cloud-based brokerages without traditional brick-and-mortar office spaces, which makes them flexible and efficient options for agents.

However, if you prefer having a place to work outside your home or a professional setting to meet clients, eXp Realty offers FREE access to over 4,000 Regus office business lounges worldwide. This gives eXp agents an extra edge for client meetings and collaborations in a formal setting.

Both brokerages are structured to provide agents with better commission splits by avoiding franchise owners’ layers, which means more money in the agents’ pockets. To understand more about that, check out the eXp Explained video found here.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Agent Satisfaction

When evaluating brokerages, agent satisfaction is one of the most important factors. On Glassdoor, eXp Realty holds a 4.6-star rating from over 3,500 reviews, while Real Broker has a strong 4.5-star rating from 109 reviews.

Notably, eXp Realty has consistently made it onto Glassdoor’s Top 100 Companies list every year from 2018 to 2024, which speaks to the consistent agent satisfaction and company culture at eXp Realty. Real Broker has not yet made it onto this prestigious list.

If you’re curious about how the top real estate firms stack up, check out our blog “12 Insider Picks for the Best Real Estate Brokerage in 2024!” Spoiler alert: eXp Realty ranks #1 on Glassdoor.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Brokerage Availability

Another key factor when selecting a brokerage is where they operate. eXp Realty is active in 50 states and 24 countries, with a powerful agent network of over 80,000 agents. This international presence offers unmatched opportunities for agents to collaborate globally, expand their client base, and build referral relationships across the world.

In comparison, Real Broker operates in 50 states and 2 countries, with around 20,000 agents. While Real Broker is growing, it doesn’t yet match the global reach and network size of eXp Realty. For agents seeking wider opportunities and broader resources, eXp Realty’s expansive network is a huge advantage.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Brokerage Profitability

Why does profitability matter to you as an agent? A financially stable brokerage can continue to invest in tools, training, and support for its agents. When brokerages struggle financially, they often start cutting back on resources or adding fees that affect your bottom line.

Real Broker has posted 19 quarters of earnings but with only 1 profitable quarter, which raises questions about its long-term financial stability especially given the new NAR rules.

In contrast, eXp Realty has posted 20 quarters of earnings, with 15 profitable quarters—a profitability rate of 75%. Additionally, eXp Realty is the only publicly traded brokerage that’s been profitable for the past five years, signaling continued stability and growth.

If you want the full scoop on brokerage profitability, check out our blog “Top Real Estate Companies That Might Go Under!”

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Commission Splits

When it comes to commission splits, this is what agents often focus on most—it determines how much of your hard-earned commission stays with you.

Real Broker offers agents an 85/15 split until they hit their $12,000 cap, after which they keep 100% of their commission. Agents at Real can also earn up to $24,000 in company stock by meeting certain production milestones.

At eXp Realty, agents start with an 80/20 split, and once they’ve paid $16,000 to the brokerage for the year, they move to 100% commission. Agents at eXp Realty also earn stock for reaching specific production goals, and agents can earn their $16,000 cap back in company stock.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Fees

Fees are another important consideration when choosing a brokerage. At Real Broker, agents pay a $249 joining fee, along with a $750 annual fee that’s collected over the first three sales each year.

There are no transaction fees until agents cap. eXp Realty keeps things straightforward, charging agents an $85 monthly fee and a $25 transaction fee per deal until they cap.

At Real Broker, agents pay $30 per sale for E&O insurance, which adds up over time but is manageable. At eXp Realty, agents pay $60 per transaction, and once you’ve paid $750 for the year, you’re capped and don’t have to pay any more E&O fees for the rest of the year.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Training and Support

The right training and support can make all the difference, no matter where you are in your real estate career.

eXp Realty offers agents access to 50+ live training sessions each week, in addition to a massive on-demand library packed with resources for both new and experienced agents. New agents can get up to speed with the Fast Start program, while more experienced agents can take advantage of the Kick Start program to refine their skills and grow their business.

On top of all that, eXp Realty offers 24/7 support from over 2,000 full-time staff members, so you’ll never be left without help.

Real Broker offers around 30+ live hours of training each week, but beyond that, information about support is unclear. If you’re looking for comprehensive, around-the-clock support, eXp Realty seems to have the edge.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Technology and Resources

Staying competitive in the real estate market means having the best tech at your fingertips, and eXp Realty excels in this area with its fully virtual setup.

Agents can do everything online, from attending training sessions to meeting with their broker, through the eXp World platform—a metaverse-style environment that allows real-time collaboration and interaction. Want more details? Check out our blog on eXp World here.

Additionally, eXp Realty provides agents with their own IDX website, a powerful kvCORE CRM, and a marketing center loaded with customizable templates for social media, flyers, and more.

Real Broker’s technology resources are less clear, and they don’t offer a metaverse-style environment like eXp World. Without detailed information on the tech available, it’s hard to draw a comparison, but eXp Realty’s extensive suite of tools is difficult to beat.

eXp Realty vs. Real Broker: Income Opportunities

When it comes to income opportunities, eXp Realty really shines, offering agents multiple ways to build long-term wealth. Beyond commission, agents can earn revenue share, receive stock production awards, and even purchase discounted stock—all designed to help agents grow their income and financial security.

While Real Broker also offers stock awards and the ability to purchase discounted stock, the revenue share pool is much smaller, at approximately $43 million, compared to eXp’s larger pool of $204 million. Additionally, Real Broker charges a $175 annual fee plus a 1.2% admin fee to participate in the revenue share program.

Another notable difference is that eXp Realty agents can offer unique value to attract agents to their sponsor line, giving them the opportunity to differentiate themselves from other sponsors. Real Broker agents, on the other hand, don’t have the ability to offer exclusive value, as all sponsors provide the same resources.

This entrepreneurial flexibility at eXp Realty gives agents an extra edge when it comes to building their revenue share. Learn more about eXp Realty’s amazing opportunity for revenue share income from our blog here.

eXp’s Exclusive Resources

Beyond the usual offerings, eXp Realty has a few game-changing features that other brokerages simply don’t provide. eXp Realty has a luxury division with global advertising around the world. eXp Realty has a dedicated team, Revenos, whose entire mission is to find and deliver top-quality leads directly to eXp agents—how great is that?

Then there’s eXp’s Referral tool that makes sending referrals to other agents effortless, and for those wanting to focus purely on referrals, eXp’s Referral Division slashes costs while keeping you active in the industry.

The bottom line is that because eXp Realty is uniquely profitable, eXp continues to innovate and provide more exclusive resources helping agents and their clients. eXp Realty works hard to maintain its tag line as the most agent-centric brokerage on the planet.

That’s a Wrap

When comparing eXp Realty to Real Broker, it’s clear that eXp Realty stands out with its larger global reach, transparent commission splits, and lower fees, along with its unparalleled training, support, and technology.

Real Broker is a solid option for agents seeking a competitive commission split and stock opportunities, but when it comes to overall value and income potential, eXp Realty holds the advantage.
